Here I will describe what the process was when I did the training. ## The importance of the R community First of all: I would like to point out that the R community was essential for me to be able to take this training. When I found out about the existence of this certification, I soon came across a difficulty to participate: on the website it said that it was necessary to pay (in dollars) to do the training. For those who are Brazilians, we know how the local currency is very devalued, and this ends up making it difficult for many Brazilian people to participate. So I let it go, until I saw a [post](https://yabellini.netlify.app/post/rstudiocertification/) on [Yanina Saibene](https://twitter.com/yabellini)'s blog talking about the training and certification that she took. She put me in touch with a group of people who are part of [several chapters of R-Ladies](https://rladies.org/) in Latin America, who were starting to organize a study group (and support!) to do the training. In addition, she also gave me more information on how to make this financially possible. For this study group, we created a Slack channel, where we shared tips, exercise resolutions and questions. In addition, we had weekly Zoom meetings to discuss chapters from the book [R for Data Science](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/) (also available in Spanish [this link](https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/)). The guidance from [Yanina Saibene](https://twitter.com/yabellini) and the support from the study group were essential for me to prepare for the exams, and to feel confident in taking them. ## Como iniciar o processo de treinamento?
